title: Why the banks will fight hard in ACCC probe
text:
David Rowe's cartoon. David Rowe

All of which means mortgages are more important to the banks than they have ever been and speaks to why the banks won’t meekly roll over in the face of yet another Frydenberg whacking.

Indeed, it was notable that Shayne Elliott – who irked Frydenberg last week with his QE summit proposal – was quickly out of the blocks on Monday, declaring that the inquiry would be a “good opportunity to provide facts in what is a complex space”.

Similarly, NAB’s chief customer and retail bank boss, Mike Baird, appears to be looking forward to putting his case.

Important opportunity

“This is an important opportunity to discuss the challenges of an increasingly low-interest-rate environment and engage in a broader discussion about how we support all our customers –- both depositors and borrowers,” he said on Monday morning.

After the detailed inquiries into the mortgage market by both the ACCC and the Productivity Commission in the past few years, it’s hard to imagine what revelations Frydenberg’s fresh probe will come up with.

Advertisement

The only really new ground is around the impact of very low-interest rates on the banking sector.

This is where the banks will surely focus.

The big four will say that with official interest rates now so close to zero, they cannot pass through the full rate cuts to deposit holders without rates going into negative territory. And so, to protect their margins – and by extension their profits, and the dividends they pay to the millions of Australians who received them – the banks simply cannot past all of the cuts in official rates through to mortgage holders.

But the big four’s problem is that this argument is both perfectly logical – particularly if you’re a bank shareholder – and unlikely to make a jot of difference in the politically charged environment in which they find themselves.

Massive profit pool

That’s mainly because, despite all the muck that’s been heaped on the big four in the last few years, their profit pool is both large and visible; they remain on track for a total cash profit of $28.3 billion in the 2019 financial year, down just 4 per cent on 2018 and on an average return on equity of 11.2 per cent.

Rightly or wrongly, it’s the size of those profits that makes the Prime Minister and Treasurer feel like they can so openly charge the banks with profiteering.

Of course, the more philosophical question of how the nation should balance financial stability with banking competition – particularly given the longstanding four pillars policy that enshrines the status quo – will likely get a much of a run here.

Advertisement

So the question for the banks and their investors is whether this inquiry might come up with any new ways to nip away at their sector’s profit pool/dividend stream.

Could, as former Productivity Commission chairman Peter Harris urged last week, a stern and strictly enforced “best interests duty” for bankers and mortgage brokers force these groups to pro-actively help customers switch into cheaper loans? (This is in train now but will likely be, ironically, held up by the new probe.)

Could the banks be forced to be more transparent about the average rate they charge mortgage holders – that is, after discounts – rather than the inflated standard rates they advertise now?

Could the government create a central rate comparison portal that actually made it easier to compare rates?

All these initiatives would chip away at bank margins and profits. But in this populist environment, the banks will likely need to give ground somewhere – or face even more government intervention.
description: The banking sector's retreat to simplicity in the wake of the royal commission means its more reliant on mortgages than ever before.
